newsitem.title: USA: U.S jobless claims point to labor market tightness.
newsitem.headline: U.S jobless claims point to labor market tightness.

text.p: A sharp drop in initial claims for state unemployment insurance undershot expectations of Wall Street economists, pointing to further evidence of labor market tightness, experts said.
Claims for the week ended February 8 fell to 309,000 from a revised 324,000 the prior week, the lowest since July 27. Economists in a Reuters poll had forecast 339,000 new claims.
"The only way you can read it is we have a very strong labor market," said Astrid Adolfson, first vice president and an economist at consulting firm MCM MoneWatch Inc.

This week's reading might still be distorted by weather effects since the numbers are reaching such low levels, Adolfson said. "Even if you assume 15,000 to 20,000 incorrect seasonals, you would still have a very strong labor market."
Claims have been volatile over the past few weeks, as they normally are in January, said Donald Maude, chief U.S. economist at Scotia Capital Markets Inc.
"But we've had two consecutive weeks of 325,000 or below," Maude said, adding that it "probably bodes for pretty decent February non-farm payrolls."
The Labor Department said the four-week moving average for initial claims slipped to 327,750 from a revised 330,750.
"The four-week average has come down and is continuing to come down," said Marilyn Schaja, money market economist at Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp.
Looking forward, however, Schaja projected jobless claims would eventually drift upward because of an eventual slowdown in the economy.
"Given the expectation of a slowdown in economic activity, it should weaken the labor market," she said.
Analysts said the 0830 EST/1330 GMT report on retail sales and the upcoming Treasury auction later in the day may have muted the government bond market's reaction to jobless claims.

"I'm encouraged that the bond market is stable, we haven't lost any ground since retail sales were released ... and don't forget you've got an auction today," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany Corp.
By 0945 EST/1445 GMT, the 30-year U.S. Treasury bond rose 5/32 to 97-16/32 bid, to yield 6.69 percent.
"I'm a little more moved by the claims number (than retail sales), which are coming down," Johnson said.
